segments.text: not to quit, not today, but 15 years ago.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Which was a lot of money.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What is it?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I like that you're waiting for the question at this point.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Honestly, where are you going to take this?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We started over.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It's rolling okay.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Can you define Neil waves?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What do you think it is?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Because I've tried and I'm kind of like conflicted.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I don't know if the messaging has gone out in the manner that it should, but what is waves really?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, my understanding is it's really the first time ever, I think, not just here in India, but really anywhere in the world where there's been such a
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: kind of meeting of everybody who has an interest and a stake in the creative industries with really the purpose of finding ways to accelerate it further.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Certainly for India and Indian culture and Indian creators, but I really think that it will have a global impact as a result.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I think, you know, kind of the insight for me at least
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: was that the recognition, certainly on part of the government, but I think the creative industries in India in general, the recognition that India really is at the cusp of being a true creator nation.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I get to see it from my vantage point at YouTube.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I see it in the numbers, I see it obviously in everybody that I interact with whenever I'm visiting India.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But I think that's the big vision.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I think what's really interesting about it is it's
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's a mix of everything.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: There's obviously the cultural and creative aspect of it, but there's also the business aspect of it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What's required to be a successful creator.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: There's also the collaborative aspect of it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: There's the private government partnership aspect, and I think waves, at least in my understanding, is trying to put all those pieces together.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Content creators and politics.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Do you think they're getting more ingrained than they have ever been?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, the way I think about it is,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Did you vote Republican or Democrat?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Did I?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I'm not gonna get into all my pieces.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I've voted on both sides for a very long time.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Let's put it that way.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You're not asking an India question, you're asking in general.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I would say it really goes back to the fact that a place like YouTube is
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yes, it's a place for content creators and creators and YouTubers.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And most of what we all consume on YouTube is entertainment or learning or what have you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But really it's an information platform.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And our mission statement is to give everyone a voice and show them the world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so if you think about that, what happens on YouTube is a reflection of what's happening in the world and vice versa.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The connection, therefore, between creativity on YouTube and politics or elections or societal conversations, if you look at it in that context, shouldn't be a surprise.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And that's what we see in the US, whether you're talking about the Republican Party or the Democratic Party.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And it's what we saw here in the elections, the gigantic elections that happened here in India last year.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: just happened in Canada yesterday and really all over the world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So if I were to make the assumption that Trump utilized content creators better in the previous election, does the platform that houses most of the content creators get to sway what should be heard since you control the narrative?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: or the narrative, but who watches which narrative?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yeah, I really don't look at it that way at all.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: In fact, I really think that it goes back to what I was saying, which is YouTube really is a reflection of what is happening in the world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And precisely, it's actually meant to be a reflection of what's interesting to you in the moment.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: When you open up the YouTube app, it really should be a reflection of Nikhil's interests.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: of the moment over some period of time.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It doesn't mean that it's just that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Obviously we endeavor to show a diversity of content, but it's generally oriented around what we know to be of your personal interests based on your viewing habits, et cetera.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So you as the user really are in the driver's seat in terms of what type of content you're looking for, what you're looking to view.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And it's the job of the content creators to be true to who they are
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: but then to use the YouTube platform to build an audience.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I say that YouTube in many ways is the most efficient way of connecting a creator like yourself with their audience wherever they are in the world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But it's really just that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You are the one responsible for actually producing the content that's interesting to people.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I as a fan of yours, I'm only gonna watch it to the extent that I'm interested.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: fundamentally what happens on YouTube.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And your question about what happened in the recent elections in the US, I do think that news commentators, podcasters or whatever you wanna call them played a big role in that election.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I do think that candidates that got the word out as a result of engagement in what, in generations past or years past would have been overlooked as an outlet.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: ended up being successful because those podcasters had large audiences that were interested in what their guests had to say.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And we saw that play out over and over.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I always say that the success of podcasts on YouTube came into focus last year.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Obviously the elections were kind of a pivotal point in the US, but it was like an overnight success many years in the making.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Because when we first started investing in podcasts,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I'm curious what your experience is on our platform.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We made like two or three really big bets that I think back then would have been kind of strange.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Well, the biggest is we bet on the fact that people would want to watch a conversation, not listen to it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Lots of people listen to podcasts on YouTube, but lots of people watch it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And obviously COVID was an accelerator when people were at homes, they wanted to see what was happening.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But there's an enormous amount of content, podcast content that's viewed, not just on mobile phones, but on television screens.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So that was one.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The second was really betting on discovery.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So discovery around not just podcasts that you're subscribed to, but like discovery around podcasts that you might be genuinely interested in.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So that was a really big part of it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So posting the podcast and going about it that way.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And then the third piece is just recognizing
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: that it's not just about building an audience for podcasters, it's also helping them monetize it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So really making it so that podcasts were integrated into our YouTube partner program monetization.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So those three bats really ended up being, I think, kind of foundational driver of our podcast strategy.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So when I think of podcasting, Neil, news has, there is no information arbitrage when somebody is reporting the news.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: For a long time, the bias of the reporter is why I might have watched one particular news channel over another.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I feel recently people have gotten disillusioned by corporations owning news channels and assume the newscaster's views will also be biased.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And a podcaster seems to be more of an independent character.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So the bias of the corporation doesn't translate onto him.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Do you think why people are
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: moving to podcast in the news information space.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yeah, that's really interesting.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I think first I would say I think there's lots of reasons why, why, um, podcasters have moved to platforms like YouTube, but also found success on it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But I think it comes down to two fundamental things.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Um, one is they would only do it if they felt that they could build an audience on YouTube so that there was,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: no barrier between them and the audience that they were looking to build.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: My question is more why is the audience choosing to know what happened in the world from a podcast versus a news media channel?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I'd say that I don't think it's an either or.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I would say, and again, just speaking from what's happening on YouTube standpoint, we see lots of success from what you would call traditional news channels.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: they have adopted the YouTube style of content.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Many of them have been investing in the platform for a very long time.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I don't mean just clips, I mean like full on live news broadcasts, replays of the broadcasts, live streams in many cases.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So really kind of all the gamut of news.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And we have seen their success on our platform as well.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Especially when people are coming to YouTube looking for information around politics to use your example.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: whatever sort of thing impacts their lives, we've seen that success.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Now, I think what a podcaster does sort of to the extent that they're related to news is that they cover the news, talk about the news, but they also are doing it through the means and the tools of a creator, right?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Like so, YouTube oftentimes is about connecting with
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: the person whose channel it is.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's not just about what they said in that one particular video.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I, as a fan, am interested in that person in general.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: How do they go about their day?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What their interests are, et cetera.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so I think the nice thing about podcasting on YouTube is it really combines both of those things.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If I were to push you a bit, Neil, and ask you a binary answer to the question, five years from today, will you be watching Fox or CNN
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: to know what happened in the world that day.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Would you be watching an independent creator on YouTube say what it is?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I really don't think it's gonna be one or the other.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Fox had one of its most successful quarters months ever on YouTube.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Just, I think just last month, they reported it themselves.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: They've been investing and credit to them, right?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: They've been investing heavily in understanding this.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But I also think alongside of that, you're gonna see
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: other types of content, like you said, podcasters be successful.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I think some of that gets at sort of the inherent nature of YouTube, which is, it really can be all of these things.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, two billion people come to the platform every single day.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The subset of them that are consuming news, there's gonna be such enormous diversity in terms of their preferences, their priorities, in terms of how they consume news on YouTube.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I just think that five years from now, you should expect to see
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: more of that diversity, not less.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think if I were predicting anything, I don't think it would be a one or zero between those two types of options.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I could very well see a third type of format get invented and find success on the platform.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That's what's amazing about the creators on YouTube is you never really know what they're going to experiment with and then come up with next.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I know it's tough to put YouTube in a box, but if you were to try and define what YouTube is today, what would you say it is?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: That's a great question.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I would say I think we are really our own thing, and what I mean by that is our ambition is to be a streaming service where you can watch, create, and share video, regardless of where you are in the world, who you are.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That's our goal, that's our mission.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And what I like about that is it really encapsulates everything from living room screens, to television screens, to your phone in your pocket, to car radio, all that sort of stuff.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We're not social media.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We're not a place where you go to connect or share with your friends.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You're primarily there to watch video.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And we're not sort of linear, traditional television either.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We're sort of our own thing because of the nature of the content that's created on our platform, being a creator-led content generation platform.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Are you more a place where content is stored and then streamed?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Do you think the technology of doing that defines YouTube more?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Or are you a curator of content which shows me what I want to see more?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I think the term curator is a bit of a loaded term.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And because we don't curate the content.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We've tried in the past.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We had something called YouTube Originals.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It wasn't successful.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So we don't do that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What we do, the analogy that I use that I think sort of works best is most of the people at YouTube are software engineers or technologists.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And our job is to build the stage.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I want that to be the best possible stage in the world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: When you come to this stage, to this theater, the most comfortable seats, the best view lines, the most amazing effects or what have you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But that's it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That's what we do.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The people that are on the stage are our creators.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so we have to create the tools and capabilities
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: that make them shine the best possible stage and make viewers really wanna keep coming back to that theater.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I think that's the best, really the best way to describe what YouTube is and what YouTube does.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So build the technology and then frankly get out of the way.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So is YouTube the show director which picks which show goes on at what time?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Or are you somebody who built the theater?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We are really someone who built the theater.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I don't tell you when to post or what you should say.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You have exercised that creative control.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Back to your point on podcasters, multiple podcasters will tell me that they've had more creative and editorial control by taking their destiny into their own hands than they ever had in sort of any other type of their profession in the past.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And that's what YouTube is.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You get to decide those things.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What I need to do for you is
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: to give you the technology that allows you to match with your audience, not just the person who subscribes to your channel, but who else might be interested in it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You produce content and have conversations that might be interesting to an English listener, somebody who understands English.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But of course, this conversation might apply to somebody speaking Spanish, or Portuguese, or Tamil, or Bengali.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I should provide you the technology, so if you choose to allow for this conversation to happen in all those languages as an example.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So that's what I mean by like, we build the theater, we kind of build the rooms in the theater, we build the stage, we build the seats, but you're the one who's on the stage.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So Neil, I'm 38 years old.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I have grown up in India, largely in Bangalore.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So my relationship with content went from watching
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Hindi TV serials growing up on TV, on traditional broadcast TV, to cricket and then maybe getting my first personal device or a medium to consume content when I was 16 or 17 years old.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: To where I sit today and you know the movie theater going experience all of that followed, where I sit today I'm trying to predict
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: where Nikhil, the 48-year-old, will be.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What content will he be consuming?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: On what medium?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Can you throw some light on that?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yeah, I would say a few things might be different in 10 years.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: First, I would say that everything we've talked about, I still think that we're in the early innings of.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Meaning that the growth of content in general, but YouTube content is
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: gonna only continue to grow on screens like the living room.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We're just getting started there.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I would say that probably the biggest early stage sort of phenomenon that I see that I'm very excited about, and actually a lot of it is being driven by what's happening here in India, is just this whole idea of like creator-led content production.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So it's like, creators are the startups of Hollywood.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I mean Hollywood, I mean Bollywood, I mean kind of just whatever pick your metaphor there.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And just like startups keep an industry vibrant, just like in Silicon Valley, creators do the same thing when it comes to the production of content.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So in 10 years, this relatively new phenomenon, which I consider at least for young people is pretty mainstream, but I think for the general population, it's not quite there yet, I think is gonna be pretty mainstream.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: When I go visit Burbank in California,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: right down the street from the largest studio in the world, 100-year-old studio, Disney, there are all of these startup studios led by creators like Rhett and Link, Alan Chick and Chow, et cetera, 10,000 square foot studios where they're producing amazing content.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's done differently.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's done in a very YouTube style.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's done with their personalities, but they're doing kind of roughly what big studios were doing before.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: They're just doing it
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: different sort of scale, different budgets, et cetera.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I think that's gonna be a really big phenomenon.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think the other one that's very exciting is the advent of AI and what AI will be able to do for creativity.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: My view is that it's really going to be a tool that enhances human creativity, never replacing it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We can talk more about that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think again, you gave the example from sort of you growing up and sort of how these various things sort of came into play for you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think if you think about it through the lens of young people today, the things that they take for granted, more things that, and I'm a little bit older than you, so I had to discover this even later in my life, they just have been having that experience from day one.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so I think one of the things that people shouldn't forget when it comes to the content world is ultimately consumers really are in charge.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: They really vote with their time and their engagement.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And today a young person almost expects all of their favorite content to really be in one place.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Everything from a 15 second short to a 15 minute vlog to an hour long podcast, 15 hour gaming live stream and four hour NFL game, three hour cricket game, they expect it to be in one place and be able to consume that on whatever surface and device that they want.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so that sort of like,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: plethora of consumer choice 10 years from now is gonna be even more dramatic than it is today because those young people have had that expectation since day one.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So building on that last thought, in the future, if you're competing with, say, Netflix for Mindshare, will you become more like Netflix or will Netflix become more like YouTube?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I mean, I think that our approach is going to be
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The approach that you've seen on YouTube, you should expect that same approach going into the future.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Like I said, we produce the stage, we will be the leaders when it comes to technology, whether it's our investment in AI and the algorithm in terms of how the product looks and feels, all the bells and whistles we build for creators, you should expect us to continue to do that, but it's gonna be our creators that actually determine that sort of creative journey where it goes.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I like that because our creators are infinitely creative.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: There are 100 million creators in India uploaded videos on YouTube.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We have 15,000 creators in India over a million subs.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: When I was here last, just a few months ago, that number was I think 11,000.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: When I first started at YouTube like 10 years ago, that number was like four or five.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So just this proliferation of amazing content, amazing creativity.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: is what YouTube is today and that's what you should expect it to be five, ten years from now too.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: For content like Hollywood and Bollywood, I've had this conversation with a friend of mine who was recently putting out a movie.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I know he did consider putting it on YouTube straight up and charging a fee, a smaller fee, albeit.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But then comes in the concern of
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: piracy, if he were not to go the theater or the multiplex route.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Do you have any thoughts about that?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: If I'm a filmmaker and I don't go to a multiplex or a theater and I come to YouTube and I release a movie there, how do you prevent somebody from copying it and republishing it?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We have, for a long time, invested very heavily in the DRM tools that
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: that try to prevent that from happening.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Now, if somebody is screen grabbing and screen taping in a particular way, it's really hard.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And there's two aspects, obviously, of piracy.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: By the way, I might be able to guess who this friend of yours is.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I've heard this feedback directly from him, so.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I watched the movie.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yeah, yeah.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It looks amazing.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yeah.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yes, yes.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: There's two aspects to piracy.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: One is the actual act of creating that copy.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And as I said, things like DRM and what we do to sort of prevent against that, at least create enough friction where it's not trivial to do.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And then the other aspect, of course, is the distribution piece, because like piracy is ultimately for viewership.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And if you can kind of choke that piece off, then that's sort of getting at one of the other use cases.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And that's where
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, the fact that lots of content is ultimately distributed on YouTube, we have that choke point around that type of content in conjunction with our policy.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So it's a two-fold approach.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's never perfect from that standpoint, but I think history has shown that we have a pretty good handle in terms of that type of content never running rampant on YouTube.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So my audience, Neil, are largely young Indian wannabe entrepreneurs.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So I think the first thing that I would say is I wouldn't describe if that's your sole goal that I would think about YouTube a bit differently.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The way I think about YouTube is it's really the home for creators.

segments.text: And I use that term creator specifically as opposed to influencer or what have you.

segments.text: Because the primary purpose of your presence and investment on YouTube has to be
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: the act of creation, about having an idea, whatever the topic, whether it's funny, whether it's sports, whether it's business, and sharing it.

segments.text: So, if that's not really fundamentally the goal, then I think it becomes a bit harder on YouTube.

segments.text: they have that connection to their audience in a way that is deeper and more authentic than they can get anywhere else.

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I can't give you any advice.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I would, again, just maybe broaden it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I would just say, I think that really YouTube is different than all of those pieces that you touched on.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, we interact with, we probably compete with some of those players that you mentioned, but our lane is different.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It really is about,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: watching, sharing and creating video, full stop.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That's what we want to do.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We want to make sure that we continue to do it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We are the world's oldest and largest creator economy.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And, you know, it's my ambition as CEO to make sure that continues to be the case.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And if I were to go back to the fact that I'm speaking to entrepreneurs who want to use this platform to grow a business, can you give me five non-obvious insights about the world of content?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: that I might not be able to find online?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Yeah, let me say a few things.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: First is, and I don't know if this is obvious or not, but I'll just, I'll say sort of the things that I think an up and coming entrepreneur would want to think about.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: One is, you know, places like YouTube, but other platforms also have really eliminated the need or the, like the fact of a barrier between you and your,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: audience or your customer or however you think about it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Like you are in the driver's seat, you get to control what that conversation looks like and you get the feedback immediately.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That's the second thing.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's like as opposed to feedback that would happen in the traditional way, whether you were an entrepreneur and getting the feedback from the market six months down the road or from your investors a year down the road.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: feedback on a place like YouTube is instantaneously.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You literally see it in the comments within minutes of you, seconds minutes within you posting the video.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So that's a world that you really, really have to be ready for.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The third we talked about, which is truly global, right?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So you can have local, regional, national sort of ambitions, but content tends to be,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Global storylines do translate.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: They are specifics, obviously, and obviously culture matters a lot, but that's kind of the third thing that I would say.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: One thing that I think was not obvious for a while, is now starting to be more obvious around content, is it truly is multi-screen, right?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Like the mental model when you say the word YouTube, what pops into your head, you might be a mobile phone.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Well, in the US, the majority of content is actually consumed on television screens.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And, you know, that could happen in the rest of the world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's our fastest growing screen.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So just, you know, kind of this multi-modality, multi-surface is super, super important.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And then I think the very last thing I'll say again from an entrepreneur standpoint is our fundamental business model is an advertising model.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And that's because we're large scale, right?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Like it is a way to reach a very large pool of people
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: with your content if it's ad supported.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But I also think that entrepreneurs should think about other types of monetization models like SVOD.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We have a subscription business with YouTube Premium.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Direct fan funding models, especially if you have niche content.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If you are creating content in a particular education vertical that is super, super valuable, but probably doesn't have broad reach.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: then a direct consumer fan funding type model might make sense.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We talked about shopping and merch and those types of use cases.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So be creative and flexible about the monetization models, but be very rock solid in terms of the content that's true to you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If all the world is stories and stage, if Neil had to quit YouTube tomorrow,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: and build YouTube's competition, because the world should not just have one, two, or three stages, but many stages.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What would you build that can compete with YouTube as a better place to tell stories?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, hopefully, if that's gonna be the case, we're doing it within YouTube.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I always say to our teams that we really do have to continue to disrupt ourselves.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That's what our creators and our viewers
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: expect whether they say it or not, they do expect that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: One area that we haven't talked a lot about, but I am very excited by, and I do think it will be disruptive, not just to YouTube, but to the creative industries in general, is AI, and everything that's happening with AI.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I think it can be disruptive up and down the stack.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What we're doing, and I'm sure lots of competition is doing, but what we're doing at YouTube is,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: How do we turn it into tools that allow for that disruption to occur because you can't bury that technological disruption but allow for it to feel like it is in the hands of the creative people?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so I'll just give you a couple of examples.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The technology exists today when you hit that plus camera on YouTube to now within a few seconds give it a text prompt of
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, let's change this set to one where we're sitting in a spring meadow and there's birds and flowers outside.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And that's probably something that would have taken us days or weeks to put together if that's what we wanted our set to be.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: AI allows you to do that now in seconds.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And that's a collaboration between YouTube and Google DeepMind.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So that's pretty profound from a user standpoint.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: As fans, we're like, wow, we get the benefit of this.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: really, really quickly, I also think it is a tool in the hands of the creator, like it was your decision or my decision to come up with that creative idea and now it's there.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so that's really cool because now this technology is in the hands of a lot more creators, but it is disruptive because it did disrupt a lot of things that needed to happen in the pre-AI scenario, right?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Like that days or weeks that it would have taken.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I don't want to be naive to that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so I just,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think that's where you're gonna see lots of really interesting disruption in a way that creates new opportunities because now 10,000 more people could produce that content than otherwise could have.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But I do recognize that it's actually also gonna disrupt certain parts of that sort of value chain or stack or whatever you wanna call it through the process.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I could give you many examples of that in the creative industry.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If I were to put back the investor hat for a second,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Let's assume OpenAI used YouTube data for Sora.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Remove like your own company from the pitch.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I think it's hard to answer who has the most data or what have you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think that data is sort of one part of the equation.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I do think that technological breakthroughs and investment in innovation is another big part of it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I get to work very closely with Google DeepMind every day, particularly in areas of audio and video, right, with the VO models, et cetera.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I see how powerful that innovation can be.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And then there's a third piece, which doesn't actually get talked about that much, but I think is also very important, which is the applications of these models.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: How do they actually show up?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: How do they show up in a way where they're useful and they capture the imagination, but not just capture the imagination once and then they're forgotten about, but then really become something mainstream.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And so I think all three of those pieces are important.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: At YouTube, our focus is really obviously working on the deep sort of technology and collaboration with DeepMind, but also just as much, turning it into tools and features.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I described this product to you called DreamScreen, which is like, you know, kind of the super interesting product.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Whoa, oh my God, you can create that amazing video out of thin air from just this quick text prompt.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Of course it's amazing, it's mind blowing.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But when we talk to our creators, when I talk to creators, they love that feature, they think it's powerful, it democratizes creation, all great stuff.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But they also talk to me things about like, you know, why don't you do something even more kind of basic and mundane, which is like, why not just give me a translation of my video in 10 big languages?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think short sort of stands on its own in the sense in that it's like, it's vertical, it's shot on a mobile phone, maybe it gets consumed more in a feed.

segments.text: That was shorts back then.

segments.text: And I think in terms of attention span, you can have a long session just consuming quote unquote short content and vice versa.
